trial_identification.studytitle: Comprehension of medicine label instructions - a pilot study in glaucoma patients.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Are large print labels, on eye medications, required by glaucoma patient's to assist their comprehension of prescribed treatment?

conditions.healthcondition: Glaucoma, medication recall, comprehension of medication instructions, compliance to treatment, visual function, severity of disease.

interventions.interventions: Written informed consent will be obtained from all paricipants. Participants will have their near vision assessed with their usual correction / glasses. Thirdly, they will be asked to recall their own eye medication use; name, dose and instructions for use for each. Finally, they will be asked 3 repeat questions on 4 sample eye drop labels. The questions are structured to allow identification of "the name of the medicine", "which eye the medicine is for" and "how often the medicine should be used". Answers will be recorded as either correct or incorrect. Participants will be presented 2 standard and 2 large print labels in a set format and permitted a few minutes to examine each before being questioned. Assessment time approximately 5-10 minutes.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Correlation between level of visual function and simultaneous ability to correctly identify information on standard print labels.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Assessed through a standard questionaire that follows the presentation of each the sample print labels.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Correlation between level of visual function and simultaneous ability to recall own eye medication name/s and instructions for use.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: This is assessed through a standard questionaire that precedes label intervention / presentation.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Identify ocular disease characteristics of patients who are detected as unable to currently read information on standard print labels.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: This information is obtained through medical history review once the participant has seen the doctor for his/her appointment at the Hospital. Set data collection form used.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Patients on any number of medication eye drops who have not had their eyes dilated in the pre-assessment clinic.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Patients that do not speak English.

trial_design.designfeatures: Endpoint - clinical evidence to support recommended large print label on eye medication dispensed at Hospital pharmacy.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Main purpose of this study is to identify if there is a need to offer of a large print label, on eye medications, to glaucoma patients that display certain visual function and disease characteristics. In turn, this may assist these patients in adhering to their prescribed treatment.
